File.Title: Neural Associations of the Substantia Innominata in the Rat: Afferent Connections

Abstract.S: The afferent connections of the substantia innominata (SI) in the rat were determined employing the anterograde axonal transport of Phaseobs vulgaris leucoagglutinin (PHA-L) and the retrograde transport of wheat germ agglutinin conjugated to horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRP), in combination with histochemical procedures to characterize the neuropil of the SI and identify cholinergic cells.
Both neurochemical and connectional data establish that the SI is organized into a dorsal and a ventral division.

Each of these divisions is strongly affiliated with a different region of the amygdala, and, together with its amygdalar affiliate, forms part of one of two largely distinct constellations of interconnected forebrain and brainstem cell groups.

The dorsal SI receives selective innervation from the lateral part of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis, the central and basolateral nuclei of the amygdala, the fundus of the striatum, distinctive perifornical and caudolatera1 zones of the lateral hypothalamus, and caudal brainstem structures including the dorsal raphe nucleus, parabrachial nucleus, and nucleus of the solitary tract.

Projections preferentially directed to the ventral SI arise from the medial part of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis, the rostra1 twothirds of the medial nucleus of the amygdala, a large region of the rat amygdala that lies ventral to the central nucleus, the medial preoptic area, anterior hypothalamus, medialmost lateral hypothalamus, and the ventromedial hypothalamus.
Both SI divisions appear to receive afferents from the dorsomedial and posterior hypothalamus, supramammillary region, ventral tegmental area, and the peripeduncular area of the midbrain.
Projections to the SI whose selectivity was not determined originate from medial prefrontal, insular, perirhinal, and entorhinal cortex and from midline thalamic nuclei.

Findings from both PHA-L and WGA-HRP experiments additionally indicate that cell groups preferentially innervating a single SI division maintain numerous projections to one another, thus forming a tightly linked assembly of structures.

In the rat, cholinergic neurons that are scattered throughout the SI and in parts of the globus pallidus make up a cell population equivalent to the primate basal nucleus of Meynert (Mesulam et al.: Neuroscience 10:11851201, '83).

PHA-L-filled axons, labelled from lectin deposits in the dorsal raphe nucleus, peripeduncular area, ventral tegmental area, or caudomedial hypothalamus were occasionally seen to approach individual cholinergic neurons in the SI, and to contact the surface of such cells with axonal varicosities (putative synaptic boutons).
Pending confirmation in an electron microscopic study, such findings suggest that several sources of innervation of the SI may provide afferents to the cholinergic cells in the region.

Introduction.S: The term "substantia innominata" (SI) has historically referred to an irregularly shaped region that reaches the ventral surface of the mammalian brain and stretches beneath the corpus striatum for most of the latter's rostrocaudal extent (Konig and Klippel, '63; Nauta and Haymaker, '69).
It is now well established, however, that a ventral extension of the globus pallidus (GP), the ventral pallidum WP) of Heimer and Wilson ('751, accounts for roughly the rostra1 third of the region.

Like the GP, the VP receives a heavy innervation from the striatum (Heimer and Wilson, '75), which is reflected by the presence in the entire VP-GP continuum of dense axon plexuses immunoreactive for Lglutamate-1-decarboxylase and met-enkephalin (Switzer et al., '82; Zaborszky et al., '82; Haber and Nauta, '83).
The efferent connections of the VP, as well, appear to parallel those of the overlying GP (Groenewegen and van Dijk, '84; Young et al., '84; Haber et al., '85; Zahm et al., '87).

Strong evidence that the VP is a component of the basal ganglia has led many investigators to reserve the term "substantia innominata'' for the comparatively poorly characterized area caudal to the VP (de Olmos et al., '85; Heimer et al., '85; Paxinos and Watson, '82, '86).

Reported here is the first of two companion studies investigating the afferent and efferent connections of this region, also referred to as the "sublenticular substantia innominata" (de Olmos et al., '85; Heimer et al., '85).
Although there has been no single comprehensive study of the efferents of the SI, it is evident the region maintains an influence over structures in many of the major subdivisions of the brain.

Recent attention has focused on projections to the amygdala and cerebral cortex from the prominent group of cholinergic cells that form the basal nucleus of Meynert in the primate, as well as from noncholinergic SI neurons (Lehmann et al., '80; Big1 et al., '82; Woolf and Butcher, '82; Grove et al., '83; McKinney et al., '83; Mesulam et al., '83a,b; Rye et al., '84b; Saper, '84; Carlsen et al., '85; Fisher et al., '86).

The SI also sends efferents as far caudal in the neural axis as the medulla, and to cell groups in the pons, midbrain and diencephalon (Jones et al., '76; Phillipson, '79; Schwaber et al., '82; Swanson et al., '84; Young et al., '84; Holstege et al., '85; Mogenson et al., '85; Levey et al., '87; Russchen et al., '87; Grove, '88).

Afferents to the SI appear to arise from similarly widespread cortical and subcortical structures that fit within the broad category of the "limbic system" (Jones et al., '76; Krettek and Price, '78a; Saper et al., '79a,b; Saper and Loewy, '80; Mesulam and Mufson, '84; Russchen et al., '85).

A systematic determination of the afferent connections of a region is particularly helpful when its anatomical and functional character is unclear, as in the case of the SI, since the cell groups that provide input may be themselves better understood.
However, investigation of the afferents of the SI is especially challenging because of its strikingly fibrous nature.
Axons traversing the SI in the ansa peduncularis and medial forebrain bundle establish numerous links between forebrain and brainstem cell groups.
Which of these fiber contingents also distribute terminals in the SI?

A problem in interpreting the results of retrograde tracer injections in such a region is that uptake and transportation by fibers that pass through the injection site without terminating cannot be discounted.
Fibers of passage have been found to take up horseradish peroxidase (HRP) and, at least when damaged, wheat germ agglutinin conjugated to HRP (WGA-HRP) (unpublished observations).
Injections of these retrograde tracers into the SI can, however, provide a survey of possible afferent sources, each of which can be further investigated with anterograde axonal a transport methods.

The Phaseolus vulgaris leucoagglutinin (PHA-L) method 1 (Gerfen and Sawchenko, '84) is an ideal anterograde circuit by tracing technique for determining the afferent and efferent connections of fibrous areas such as the SI.

Under specified ing delivery conditions (Gerfen and Sawchenko, '84), PHA-L is not taken up by axons passing through the injection site, an advantage it shares with the autoradiographic antero50 grade tracing technique.

Unlike the latter, however, the PHA-L method allows, at the light microscope level, a reliable distinction of labelled axon terminals from nonterminating axon segments (Gerfen and Sawchenko, '84; Wouterlood and Groenewegen, '85; Grove and Ingham, '86), even at in regions where the terminals are sparse or are IooseIy scattered among labelled fibers of passage.

The present study in the rat examines the afferent conin nections of the SI, employing the anterograde axonal transport of PHA-L and retrograde transport of WGA-HRP, in as combination with histochemical procedures to characterize of the neuropil of the SI and identify cholinergic cells.
In brief, both histochemical and connectional data obtained in the 40 present study indicate that the SI is organized into a dorsal and a ventral division.

The afferent connections of the SI, as well as its efferent projections, which are the subject of a subsequent paper (Grove, '88), indicate each SI division is strongly affiliated with a different part of the amygdala, and, together with its amygdalar affiliate, forms part of one ing of two distinct constellations of interconnected forebrain and brainstem cell groups.

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS
For all experiments in the present study, adult, female, albino rats (CD strain) were obtained from Charles River Laboratories.

During surgical procedures, and before transcardial perfusion of fixatives, the animals were deeply anesthetized with Chloropent, a veterinary anesthetic containing chloral hydrate and pentobarbital (obtained for these experiments from Ft.
Dodge Labs, but no longer available from this source). and Retrograde tracing experiments
Wheat germ agglutinin conjugated to horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRP) (Sigma) was dissolved in Tris-buffered saline, pH 7.6, to a 5-10% solution.
Deposits of WGA-HRP were placed in the basal forebrain of sixteen rats.

Small tracer injections with little or no spread along the pipette track were consistently obtained by applying 2 pA of direct current (Midgard constant-current source), for 2-5 minutes, through a glass pipette with a tip diameter of 10-15 pm.
Passing current for 10-15 minutes produced larger but less well-confined injections.

Twenty-four to 72 hours after surgery animals were perfused transcardially with 50 ml saline, followed by 500 ml of 2% glutaraldehyde and 0.5% paraformaldehyde, or 2% paraformaldehyde and 0.1% glutaraldehyde, in 0.1 M phosphate buffer, pH 7.4, and a final rinse of 100 ml 3% sucrose in the same buffer.
After overnight rinsing in 30% sucrose in phosphate buffer, the brains were cut on a freezing microtome in the transverse plane at 50 pm into six series.
Two standard procedures were employed to demonstrate HRP with tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) as the chromagen (Mesulam, '78; de Olmos et al., '78).
Tissue sections were counterstained with Neutral Red.
Anterograde tracing experiments
PHA-L, obtained from Vector Labs, was reconstituted as 2% solution in 0.05 M Tris-buffered saline (TBS), pH 7:6.

Glass pipettes, tip diameter 5-10 pm, were filled with about p1 of this solution, and PHA-L was deposited in the brain passing through the solution a pulsed current (5 FA, 7 seconds on, 7 seconds off) for 10-60 minutes, varying accordto the area of the brain injected.
In all, PHA-L injections were made in 65 animals.

After 4-8 days, the rats were perfused transeardially with ml of saline, followed by fixative (up to 500 ml in 15-20 minutes) consisting of either 4% paraformaldehyde or 2% paraformaldehyde and 0.1% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer, pH 7.4.
The brains were stored in phosphate buffer, and, after a standard delay of 2-16 hours, sectioned 30-50 pm into six series using an Oxford Vibratome.
PHA-L was localized with a peroxidase-antiperoxidase (PAP) procedure.
Sections were first rinsed for 60 minutes Tris-buffered saline (TBS), pH 7.6, 0.5 M, containing 1% Triton-X.

The tissue was then washed for 30-60 minutes, after each subsequent incubation step, in three changes plain TBS, and transferred to TBS plus primary antiserum, goat anti-PHA-L (Vector Laboratories) (MOO), for hours at 4°C.

Sections were next incubated in TBS plus rabbit antigoat IgG (1:40) (Antibodies Inc.), followed by TBS plus peroxidase-antiperoxidase (PAP), raised in goat (1:lOO) (Sternberger-Meyer Immunochemicals, Inc.).
Both steps were carried out at room temperature for 60 minutes.
Sections were presoaked for 15 minutes in a solution contain0.05% diaminobenzidine (DAB) in Tris buffer, pH 7.6, 0.05 M, then hydrogen peroxidase was added to a final concentration of 0.01%.
The chromagen reaction was allowed to proceed for 10-30 minutes, and stopped by transferring the sections to phosphate buffer.
An adequate Nissl counterstain of these tissue sections could be obtained with Cresyl Violet.

When' PHA-L and choline acetyltransferase (ChAT) immunoreactivity was to be localized in the same tissue sections, rat anti-ChAT (Boehringer Mannheim) (1:500) was added to the primary incubation medium, rabbit anti-rat IgG (Antibodies Incorporated) was added to the secondary, PAP, raised in rat (Sternberger-Meyer), was added to the PAP incubation step.
Control sections were incubated through the whole procedure, omitting either the ChAT or PHA-L primary antibodies.
Although the same chromagen, DAB, marked both forms of immunoreactivity, examination of control sections showed that the two could be distinguished by features described below.
Additional control sections were processed to reveal ChAT immunoreactivity alone by including in the protocol only anti-ChAT primary antiserum and the appropriate secondary antiserum and PAP complex.
Additional histochemical procedures
From each brain in which PHA-L deposits were placed, one series of tissue sections was processed to locate metenkephalin-like immunoreactivity (ENK-IR) instead of PHA-L.

A PAP technique similar in outline to that described above was employed, with the exceptions that 0.5% Triton-X was added to all incubation media to optimize staining, the primary antiserum was rabbit anti-ENK (donated by Dr.
R.
Elde), the secondary antiserum was goat antirabbit IgG (Antibodies Incorporated), and the PAP complex was raised in rabbit (Sternberger-Meyer).
Three additional brains were used to determine the extent and some histochemical features of the SI.
These were perfused as above and sectioned in the transverse plane at 30 pm into six series.

Complete series of tissue sections through the basal forebrain were stained to reveal Nissl substance (Cresyl Violet), or acetylcholinesterase activity (Geneser-Jensen and Blackstad, '71), or were processed immunohistochemically to reveal enkephalin, choline acetyltransferase, or tyrosine hydroxylase (TH) immunoreactivities.

The PAP procedure used to reveal TH immunoreactivity was identical to that employed to localize enkephalin except that the primary antiserum was rabbit antityrosine hydroxylase (Eugene Tech International).

Results.S: RESULTS
The substantia innominata : topographic relations and some histochemical features
The SI appears in Nisslor myelin-stained material to be an amorphous region with few clear boundaries.
However, two striking anatomical features are characteristic of the SI and these were used to determine its extent.

In the rat the SI 1 ) contains scattered cholinergic perikarya and 2 ) caudal to the ventral pallidum , is densely traversed by axons of the ansa peduncularis , a fiber system linking the diencephalon with the amygdala and certain ventral cortices ( Nauta and Haymaker , ' 69 ) .

In keeping with standard terminology in the rat , the nucleus of the horizontal limb of the diagonal band ( NHDB ) is not included under the term SI ( Konig and Klippel , ' 63 ; Paxinos and Watson , ' 82, ' 86 ) , even though it meets the two criteria .
Supporting such a convention, in several histochemical and connectional respects the NHDB differs from the overlying SI (Ottersen '80; de Olmos et al., '85; and see below).
For example, in Timm-stained preparations the SI displays modest, even staining, but the NHDB is almost free of reaction product (Ottersen, '80; de Olmos et al., '85).
Figure 1 shows the extent of the SI according to the two criteiia given above.

Cholinergic perikarya were identified by ChAT immunoreactivity , and the course of the ansa peduncularis was determined from cases described below in which deposits of the anterograde tracer PHA - L were placed in amygdalar and hypothalamic sites .
Rostromedially , the SI merges with the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis ( BNS )( Fig . 1B , C ) , which contains sparse cholinergic cells .

Caudal to the VP , as the NHDB dwindles , the SI broadens dorsoventrally ( Fig . 1D - F ) to its widest extent and its dorsal half fades without a clear boundary into the medial division of the rostral central nucleus of the amygdala ( Ace ) ( Fig . lE , F ) , which , likewise , contains several cholinergic cells .

The ventral half of the SI blends laterally into the anterior amygdaloid area ( AAA ) ( Fig . 1D , E ) and curves down between the caudal NHDB and the nucleus of the lateral olfactory tract ( NLOT ) ( Fig . 1E ) into an ill - defined region that is replaced caudally by the medial nucleus of the amygdala ( AM ) ( Fig . 1F ) .

Medially , the SI extends into the cellular interstices of the inferior thalamic peduncle ( ITP ) and this fiber tract, together with the medial fore , - bundle ( Fig . lE ) , separates the SI from the lateral preoptic area and lateral hypothalamus .
Drawn according to the two criteria given above , the dorsal boundary of the SI is similar to that shown by Paxinos and Watson ( ' 86 ) in their atlas of the rat brain .
However, the SI illustrated here appears slightly more extensive ventrally.
(Compare, e.g., Paxinos and Watson, '86, Fig. 23, and Fig. 1D,E from the present study.)

Although the GP is distinguished from the SI by lying dorsal to the dense fiber traffic of the ansa peduncularis, the ventromedial and caudal GP resemble the SI in containing many cholinergic perikarya (Fig. 1D-G).

These cells are particularly numerous in the cellular interstices of the internal capsule , most of which display connectional and neurochemical features of pallidal tissue ( Haber et al . , ' 85 ; Grove et al . , ' 861, including the presence of a terminal configuration characteristic of the VP and GP ( Haber and Nauta , ' 83, the enkephalin - immunoreactive ( ENK - IRI " woolly fiber " ( Fig . 1D - F ) .
ENK - IR woolly fibers not only fill the VP and GP but also invade the lateral BNS ( Haber and Nauta , ' 83 ) and the dorsalmost SI ( Fig . 1B - F ) .

The continuity of the ENK - IR plexus is , however , broken by an inlet , free of ENK - IR woolly fibers , and filled by a dense grouping of cholinergic cells , first oriented vertically ( Fig . 1B , C , arrowheads ) , then near - horizontally ( Fig . lD , arrowhead ) .

This peculiar feature , reminiscent of the cholinergic cell clusters of the primate basal nucleus of Meynert ( BNM ) , intervenes between the continuous mass of the lateral BNS and rostromedial SI on one side and the VP and GP on the other ( Fig . 1B - D ) .

A different ENK - IR axon terminal configuration , namely a field of dotlike immunoreactive " puncta , " pervades the rest of the SI ( not shown ) and emphasizes the continuity of the SI with parts of the adjacent hypothalamus and amygdala , which exhibit a similar feature .

By contrast , at least most of the nucleus of the horizontal limb of the diagonal band is conspicuously pale in ENK - stained material , further indicating that the NHDB and overlying SI can be distinguished on neurochemical and connectional grounds .
The extent of a terminal field of tyrosine hydroxylaseimmunoreactive ( TH - IR ) fibers , illustrated in Figure 2, reveals several features of the SI and adjacent structures .

At rostral levels ( Fig . 2A , B ) , a loose - woven plexus of TH - IR fibers displaying axon terminals , representing a light to moderately dense innervation , pervades lateral and ventral parts of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis , intruding only minimally into the ventral pallidum .

Slightly more caudally , the TH - IR plexus reaches into the most rostromedial SI ( Fig . 2C ) and a second patch of TH - IR varicose fibers appears in the rostral part of the central nucleus of the amygdala .
The ventral pallidum intervenes , containing only small islands of labelled varicose axons ( Fig . 2C ) .

Caudal to the VP , the TH - IR fiber plexus sweeps across the SI , com pleting the lateral BNS - SI - Ace continuum ( Fig . 2D ) and defining a dorsal division of the SI , including but not limited to the dorsalmost strip of the SI that is pervaded by ENK - IR woolly fibers .
The GP , like the VP , is filled with thick , smooth , presumably nonterminating ,TH - IR fibers en route to the striatum ( not shown ) .

Only along the lateral face of the internal capsule do small patches of slender , varicose TH - IR fibers appear , loosely continuous with the light terminal field that fills the dorsal SI ( Fig . 2C - E ) .

comment The TH - IR terminal field described above distinguishes a dorsal from a ventral division in the SI and emphasizes the continuity of the lateral BNS , dorsal SI , and central nucleus of the amygdala .

Further , the TH - IR terminal plexus generally distinguishes the dorsal SI from the ventral pallidum and overlying GP yet also reveals a similarity between the SI and at least a limited part of the cholinergic cell - rich region of the GP .

The presence of ENK - IR woolly fibers , a feature typical of pallidal tissue , might suggest that the dorsalmost strip of the SI ( as drawn by Paxinos and Watson , ' 82, ' 86 ; de Olmos and his colleagues , ' 85 ; and the present author ) is best considered an extension of the globus pallidus , similar to the VP .
In the monkey, ENK-IR woolly fibers similarly extend into the intermediate and caudal parts of the BNM (Russchen et al., '85).

However , before identifying a region as pallidal it should perhaps also be found to display such characteristic features as a reciprocal connection with the striatum , which provides the ENK - IR axonal component of the woolly fiber in the VP and GP ( Haber and Elde , ' 81 ; Zaborszky et al . , ' 82 ; Haber and Nauta , ' 83 ) , the presence of a typically pallidal cell population described by Fox et al . ( ' 74 ) , and , possibly , a second reciprocal connection with the subthalamic nucleus ( Graybiel and Ragsdale , ' 79 ) .
The question of whether the dorsalmost strip of the SI meets these criteria is discussed further below, but a conclusive characterization of this district is beyond the scope of the present study.
Instead, the afferent connections of the entire SI will be investigated, without prejudice as to whether the dorsalmost SI should ultimately be viewed as, or as mixed with, pallidal tissue.

The feature of the dorsalmost SI that is of greatest interest here - and defines it as part of the SI distinct from the overlying GP - is the passage of the dorsal third of a dense band of fibers composing the ansa peduncularis .

Findings presented below, and in a companion study (Grove, 88), indicate that this feature determines several of the afferent and efferent connections of the dorsalmost SI; thus the Iatter bears a strong connectional similarity to the rest of the SI, traversed by the ventral two-thirds of the ansa peduncularis.
Afferents to the substantia innominata and the cholinergic cell - rich region of the globus pallidus surveyed with the retrograde transport of WGA - HRP

Deposits of WGA - HRP were placed in several sites within the basal forebrain ( Fig . 3 ) to survey possible afferents to three regions : the ventral and dorsal divisions of the SI , distinguished above on neurochemical grounds , and the cholinergic cell - rich portion of the GP .
All three regions can be characterized by shared projections to the cortex and amygdala.
Case RHSZl.

TTE.S: In case RHSIl an injection of WGA - HRP was centered in the dorsal SI , with some spillage of the tracer along the pipette track in the medial GP .
Retrogradely labelled cells were found in numerous structures , almost all of which were noted to lie along either the ansa peduncularis or medial forebrain bundle .
Cell labelling at rostral levels in this brain appeared in the SI , the fundus of the striatum , and in the lateral part of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis ( Fig . 4A , B ) .
A little more caudally , cells were labelled in the central nucleus of the amygdala , particularly its medial segment , and in the basolateral nucleus ( Fig . 4B - D ) .
Additionally , a few WGA - HRP - filled cells appeared in a region ventral to the central nucleus and dorsal to the cortical nuclei of the amygdala ( Fig . 4C ) .
In the present study , no subnuclear boundaries have been drawn in the part of the amygdala just mentioned , except for those marking the intercalated nuclei .
Such boundaries were identified with reference to tissue sections stained to reveal Nissl substance, acetylcholinesterase activity, or enkephalin or tyrosine hydroxylase immunoreactivities.
None of these stains revealed clear subnuclear borders in the region ventral to the central nucleus .

In comparison , however , it should be noted that several authors have successfully identified a rostral portion of the basomedial nucleus ( ABM ) in part of this region ( Krettek and Price , 78b ; de Olmos et al . , 85 ; Paxinos and Watson , 86 ) , and Paxinos and Watson ( 86 ) indicate that much of the rest of this amygdaloid district may be occupied by an intra - amygdaloid division of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis ( see their Figs . 28 - 32 ) .

In the hypothalamus , marked concentrations of WGAHRP - filled cells appeared in a distinctive perifornical region of the lateral hypothalamus ( LH ) that also containsenkephalin - immunoreactive woolly fibers streaming medially from the entopeduncular nucleus ( Fig . 40, and in a triangular , caudolateral zone of the LH , just medial to the subthalamic nucleus ( STH ) ( Fig . 4D , E ) .
(Note that the perifornical nucleus identified by other authors (Paxinos and Watson, 86) seems to be caudal to the perifornical zone indicated here.)
Cell labelling in the STH itself may have been due to the spread of the injection site into the medial GP .
A modest concentration of labelled cells could also be seen in the LH just ventral to the fornix at relatively caudal levels ( Fig . 4D , E ) .

A few perikarya were labelled in the lateralmost part of the lateral preoptic area ( LPO ) , dorsomedial hypothalamus ( DMH ) ( Fig . 4D ) , posterior hypothalamus ( PH )( Fig . 4E ) , and supramammillary region ( SUM ) ( Fig . 4F ) .
The perifornical and caudolateral zones of the lateral hypothalamus that contained labelled cells in this case are marked out connectionally in other ways , to be described in more detail below .

For example , dense clusters of retrogradely labelled cells filled the two districts ( Fig . 5 ) after a WGA - HRP injection in the dorsomedial medulla ( case RHM1, Grove , ' 88 ) that involved the nucleus of the solitary tract and dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus .

Similarly striking cell labelling in these small subregions of the LH followed deposits of the tracer in the central nucleus of the amygdala ( case RHCEB ) or parabrachial nucleus ( RHPBG , Grove , ' 88 ) .
In the thalamus of case RHSI1, cells were labelled in the parafascicular nucleus ( PF ) ( Fig . 4D ) , and medial to PF where the midline thalamus merges with the central gray of the midbrain .

Since no other case with a WGA - HRP deposit involving the SI contained back - filled cells in the parafascicular nucleus , such labelling in RHSIl may have been due , again , to a spread of the WGA - HRP deposit into the GP , or to uptake by fibers passing through the injection site .

A continuum of labelled cells stretched caudolaterally from the parvocellular part of the subparafascicular nucleus of the thalamus ( SPF , arrowheads , Fig . 4D - F ) , into the peripeduncular area ( PPA ) of the midbrain ( Fig . 4G ) .

Caudal to the diencephalon , labelled perikarya appeared within cell groups organized along two trajectories in the midbrain and pons , dividing in the rostral midbrain and rejoining at more caudal levels , corresponding closely to the bifurcating course of the medial forebrain bundle ( Nauta and Domesick , ' 82 ) .

Thus , cells were labelled in the ventral tegmental area ( VTA ) ( Fig . 4F , G ) , substantia nigra pars compacta ( SNpc ) Pig . 4G ) , the region of cell group A8 ( Fig . 4H ) , nucleus linearis of the raphe ( Fig . 4G ) , dorsal raphe nucleus ( DR ) ( Fig . 4H ) , central gray ( Fig . 4H ) , locus coeruleus ( Fig . 41 ) , and both medial and lateral subdivisions of the parabrachial nucleus ( PB ) ( Fig . 41 , J ) .

Results.S: Case RHCHS.

TTE.S: In case RHCHS , the WGA - HRP deposit was centered in the ventral SI , spreading into the caudal portion of the nucleus of the horizontal limb of the diagonal band ( NHDB ) ( Fig . 3B ) .
In the caudal brainstem , labelled neurons were distributed in a pattern similar to that in case RHSIl but were markedly fewer .
Further , a strikingly different and complementary pattern of cell labelling appeared in the basal forebrain .

The central and basolateral nuclei of the amygdala contained few WGA - HRP - filled perikarya , but such cells were numerous in the ventral and medial amygdala , including the medial nucleus , the cortical nuclei , the region ventral to ACe ( Fig . 6A , B ) , and the anterior amygdaloid area .
Only a few cells were labelled in the lateral part of the BNS , and many more were evident in medial and posterior portions of the nucleus .
Additionally , perikarya were labelled in piriform cortex ( Fig . 6A , B ) , and in the most ventral part of insular cortex .
In the hypothalamus , WGA - HRP - filled neurons were distributed in the medial ( MPO ) and lateral preoptic areas and anterior hypothalamic area ( AH ) .

More caudally ( Fig . 6A , B ) , cell labelling was loosely dispersed in the LH , with several labelled perikarya in the most medial LH but no evident concentration in the perifornical or caudolateral zones strikingly marked out in case RHSI1.
Similar to that case , however , a small cluster of WGA - HRP - filled cells appeared just ventral to the fornix ( Fig . 6B ) .

Additional cells were labelled in the dorsomedial hypothalamus , posterior hypothalamus and supramammillary region , but , unlike the previous case , the ventromedial and arcuate nuclei ( Fig . 6A ) as well as the premammillary area also contained a few labelled perikarya .

Results.S: Case RHBNl.

TTE.S: In case RHBN1, a large WGA - HRP injection involved the ventral and dorsal SI and part of the rostral amygdala , but not the NHDB ( Fig . 3C ) .
Labelled neurons appeared in all the hypothalamic , amygdaloid , and brainstem sites that contained such cells in RHSIl and RHCHS .
Apparently because of the large volume of tracer injected , cell labelling was in all these areas more profuse than in cases RHSIl or RHCHS .
The SPF - PPA continuum , in particular , was marked by numerous WGA - HRP - filled neurons .

Further cell labelling appeared , sparsely , in the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus ( PVH ) and the midline thalamus , including the paratenial , paraventricular , central medial , rhomboid , and reuniens nuclei .
In the lower brainstem , a few labelled perikarya were identified in the nucleus subcoeruleus and nucleus of the solitary tract .
Figure 7 illustrates the distribution of WGA - HRP - filled perikarya observed in the cortex in cases RHBNl and RHCH9.
Both cases were marked by large injection sites and by abundant cortical cell labelling .
Nonetheless , all such labelling taken together marked out only selected areas of the cortical mantle .
Thus , many labelled cells were identified in medial prefrontal , insular , perirhinal , piriform and entorhinal cortices ( Fig . 7 ) .

By contrast , very few neurons were labelled in areas on the lateral convexity of the cortex or along the medial face of the hemisphere caudal to the genu of the corpus callosum ( divisions in medial prefrontal cortex , Fig . 7, according to Beckstead , 79 ) .

Results.S: Cases RHCE2 and RHBMl.

TTE.S: The subcortical distribution of cells labelled following injections of WGA - HRP into the SI strongly resembled that reported to result from retrograde tracer injections into the amygdala Weening , ' 78 ; Ottersen and Ben - Ari , ' 79 ; Aggleton et al . , ' 80 ; Mehler , ' 80 ; Norita and Kawamura , ' 80 ; Ottersen , ' 80 ; Mehler et al . , ' 81 ) .
Several cases available to the present study allowed direct comparisons.

Following an injection of WGA - HRP centered at a midcaudal level of the central nucleus of the amygdala ( RHCEZ ) ( Fig . 3D ) , not spreading into the SI , labelled cells were distributed in a pattern almost exactly matching that noted in case RHSIl with a dorsal SI injection ( Fig . 4 ) .

A few differences included the absence of labelled cells in the subthalamic nucleus and the parafascicular nucleus of the thalamus ( possibly due in RHSIl to tracer uptake by fibers passing through or terminating in the medial globus pallidus , which was minimally invaded by the WGA - HRP deposit ) .
