Discussion.S: DISCUSSION

Two features characteristic of the SI can be used to define the extent of the region: the presence of dispersed cholinergic cells and the passage of numerous fibers belonging to the ansa peduncularis (AP).
The AP is a voluminous fiber system that includes the ventral amygdalofugal pathway and the inferior thalamic peduncle.

It is largely composed of axons coursing between the diencephalon and the amygdala and ventral cortical areas but is joined by fibers from more caudal sites, for example, the parabrachial nucleus, en route to the amygdala and cortex.
Findings from the present PHA-L study show that the AP not only traverses the SI but also terminates densely within the region.
Thus, just as the nucleus of the diagonal band receives its name from the diagonal band of Broca, so could the SI aptly be termed an interstitial nucleus of the AP.

Although some Ap fibers distribute over the ventral pallidum, for the most part they appear to course around this component of the basal ganglia (Figs. 2, 8-11), further distinguishing the VP from the caudally adjacent region for which the term SI is now commonly reserved (Paxinos and Watson, '82, '86).
In addition to AP fibers, axons originating from several cell groups along the medial forebrain bundle as well as fibers from the internal capsule and diagonal band of Broca distribute over the SI.

Observations from WGA-HRP experiments, confirmed with the anterograde PHA-L circuit tracing technique, indicate that the SI is thus innervated by cell groups in many of the major subdivisions of the brain.

Specifically, in close agreement with a previous WGA-HRP study in the monkey (Russchen et al., '85), retrograde tracer experiments suggested fibers afferent to the rat SI arise from prefrontal, insular, and temporal cortices, the fundus of the striatum, widespread regions of the amygdala and hypothalamus, midline thalamic nuclei, the peripeduncular area, ventral tegmental area, substantia nigra, dorsal raphe, central gray, parabrachial nucleus, locus coeruleus, subcoeruleus, and the nucleus of the solitary tract.
Most of these projections were confirmed with anterograde tracing methods.
(Notably, however, a significant innervation from the substantia nigra could not be labelled by PHA-L deposits in that site.)
Surprisingly, given the uniform appearance of the SI in Nisslor myelin-stained material, two lines of evidence, neurochemical and connectional, indicate the region is organized into two divisions.

Dorsal and ventral subregions are distinguished by the selective termination of fibers immunoreactive for tyrosine hydroxylase, and, in retrospect, it appears likely that the same divisions were revealed by differential staining in cupric-silver preparations from normal brains (de Olmos, '72) and by the distribution of angiotensin-11-containing fibers (Lind et al., '85, Plates 8-17).
PHA-L experiments disclosed that axons from severa1 sources selectively terminate in one or the other of the two neurochemically distinct divisions.
In the present study such selective afferents were shown with the PHA-L method to arise from different Parts ofthe amYgdala and hYPotha1amus and from the caudal brainstem.'

Findings from WGAHRP experiments and from studies in other laboratories summarized below suggest that additional brainstem and cortical sites may also project preferentially to one of the two SI subregions.

Immediately dorsal to the main pathway of the AP, and thus outside the SI as it is defined in the present study, a third region composed of the ventromedial and caudal GP also contains numerous cholinergic cells.

Part of this cholinergic cell-rich region, which extends into the cellular interstices of the internal capsule, has been referred to as the basal nucleus of Meynert in the rat (Big1 et al., '82; Paxinos and Watson, '861, a term which, however, neglects the additionally pallidal nature of the area (Haber et al., '85; Grove et al., '86).

Findings from the present series of PHAL experiments indicate that the cholinergic cell-rich region of the GP shows some additional similarity to the SI by sharing, sparsely, afferents from several sources that do not innervate the dorsolateral GP.
The purpose of the present study was not only to uncover further detail regarding the afferent connections of the SI but also to determine general features of its neural associations.

From the foregoing account two principal findings emerge, both of which provide a context for further consideration of the afferent connections of the dorsal and ventral SI divisions and the cholinergic cell-rich region of the globus pallidus.
Afferents ofthe SI strongly resemble those of the amygdala

Moderate or heavy projections to the SI arise from most subdivisions of the rostra1 two-thirds of the amygdala (present study; Krettek and Price, '78a; Russchen et al., '85), which also receives a widespread return innervation from the SI (Russchen, '82; Aggleton et al., '87; Grove, '88).

Indicating a still closer affiliation with the amygdala, findings from both WGA-HRP and PHA-L experiments demonstrate a strong similarity between the afferent connections of the amygdala and those of the SI.

Specifically, the lateral part of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis, dorsal SI, and central nucleus of the amygdala share numerous afferents from elsewhere in the amygdala, the diencephalon, and caudal brainstem.
A second tissue continuum marked by common subcortical innervation is formed by a ventromedial region of the amygdala, the ventral SI, and the medial BNS.

These findings, together with those described in a companion report (Grove, '881, provide substantial documentation to support an emerging view of a forebrain continuum composed of elements of the BNS, SI, and amygdala.

It has long been recognized that the amygdala and BNS may form a single anatomical entity (Johnston, '23), and several more recent reports have suggested that they are continuous through the SI (for review, see de Olmos et al., '85).
In particular, an affiliation between the lateral part of the BNS and the central nucleus of the amygdaIa has been well documented.
The two structures contain neurons with similar morphological features (McDonald, '831, as well as several of the same types of peptidergic cell groups (Woodhams et al., '83).
Some of the latter contribute to common descending projections to the brainstem (Gray and Magnuson, '87).

A tissue continuum stretching from the lateral BNS, through the SI, into the central nucleus of the amygdala has been previously identified in cupric-silver preparations from normal brains (de Olmos, '72) and shown to be marked by connections with the basolateral nucleus of the amygdala (de Olmos, '72; Krettek and Price, '78a) and several brainstem structures (Ricardo and Koh, '78; Saper and Loewy, '80; Schwaber et al., '82; Holstege et al., '85).

An analogous affiliation between the medial segment of the BNS and the medial nucleus of the amygdala has also been proposed (de Olmos et al., '85; Holstege et al., '85) and supported by observations that both maintain connections with the accessory olfactory system and medial hypothalamus (for review, see de Olmos et al., '85).

A priori, the marked connectional distinctions between the lateral BNS and central nucleus of the amygdala on the one hand, and the medial BNS and medial amygdaloid nucleus on the other, would suggest that the two pairs are likely to be continuous through distinguishable parts of the SI.
Indeed, de Olmos and his colleagues ('85) have previously proposed a parcellation of the SI into posteroventral and anterodorsal sectors, citing unpublished observations by de Olmos and Beltramino.

No rostrocaudal differences were noted in the SI in the present study, but the same affiliation is proposed between dorsal and ventral parts of the SI and, respectively, the central amygdala-lateral BNS and the medial amygdaloid nucleus-medial BNS.
The present study has focused primarily on the subcortical afferents of the SI.
However, cortical projections to the SI may also resemble afferent connections of the amygdala.

Following large deposits of WGA-HRP into the SI, labelled cells appeared in medial prefrontal, piriform, insular, perirhinal, and entorhinal cortices, which also project to the amygdala in the rat (for review, see de Olmos et al., '85).

The results of a small number of PHA-L injections into the cortex, to be described in greater detail in a separate report, confirmed projections to the SI from at least the rostromedial prefrontal, insular, and entorhinal cortex, all of which send efferents through ventral parts of the internal capsule (IC) andor the ansa peduncularis.

By contrast, fibers labelled from PHA-L deposits in cingulate cortex caudal to the genu of the corpus callosum, or in motor cortex, coursed through more dorsal parts of the IC and did not appear to form terminal structures within the SI or amygdala.

A comparison of previous studies reveals that large injections of retrograde tracers into the SI or amygdala in the monkey label cells of apparently similar distribution in subcortical structures (Aggleton et al., '80; Mehler, '80; Norita and Kawamura, '80; Mehler et al., '81; Russchen et al., '85).

Additionally, Russchen and her colleagues ('85) have noted that those cortical areas demonstrated with the autoradiographic technique to project to the SI in the monkey (Mesulam and Mufson, '84; Russchen et al., '85) are also strongly interconnected with the amygdala (Aggleton et al., '80; Turner et al., '80; Mufson et al., '81; Amaral and Price, '84).

Both groups of investigators (Mesulam and Mufson, '84; Russchen et al., '85) concur that orbital, insular, and rostra1 temporal cortices project to the SI but that there is little direct innervation of the SI from the rest of the corticaI mantle, including sensory and motor cortex and several association areas.
The dorsal and ventral divisions of the SI are associated with two largely distinct constellations of interconnected forebrain and brainstem cell groups
The dorsal and ventral SI are not only interconnected with different parts of the amygdala, with which they share numerous afferent connections.

Additionally, as illustrated in Figure 16, each division, together with affiliated parts of the amygdala, belongs to one of two sets of systematically interconnected cell groups lying along the ansa peducularis and medial forebrain bundle.
Previous studies, cited below, have shown connections among elements of each set that were confirmed in the present study with the PHA-L method.

New information was obtained from cases with injections of anterograde or retrograde tracers in the ventral and dorsal SI, lateral and medial BNS, and regions such as the caudolateral zone of the lateral hypothalamus that were selected specifically for their apparent association with one or the other SI division (see also Grove, '88).
Neural associates of the dorsal SZ.

Present findings from PHA-L and WGA-HRP experiments, summarized in Figure 16, demonstrate that subcortical forebrain afferents preferentially directed to the dorsal division of the SI arise from the lateral part of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis, both medial and lateral subdivisions of the central nucleus, the basolateral nucleus, and the lateralmost parts of the preoptic area and lateral hypothalamus, including the distinctive perifornical and caudolateral zones.

Multiple, selective interconnections associate the lateral BNS, dorsal SI, medial central nucleus, and perifornical and caudolateral zones of the lateral hypothalamus (present study, Krettek and Price, '78; Swanson and Cowan, '79; Price and Amaral, '81; Grove, '88).

The dorsomedial hypothalamus is one of a few regions that innervate both SI divisions, and it is (or appears likely to be) additionally interconnected with each region just named, as well as with the forebrain associates of the ventral SI (present study; Saper et al., '79a; Swanson and Cowan, '79; Luiten and Room, '80; Berk and Finkelstein, '81; Price and Amaral, '81; Grove, '88).
The paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus may also innervate the SI and certainly receives a projection from the SI (Grove, '88).

Although no information was obtained to confirm a preferential connection with the dorsal division, PHA-L experiments did demonstrate projections to the PVH from the lateral BNS, central nucleus of the amygdala, and caudolateral LH, but not from comparable forebrain associates of the ventral SI (present study, Grove, '88).

Retrograde tracer experiments suggest a heavier innervation of the dorsal rather than ventral SI from the caudal brainstem, and the results of PHA-L injections confirm such preferential projections from the dorsal raphe (for which, however, only a weak selectivity is evident) and parabrachial nucleus.
(The lateral PB appears to provide a strikingly heavier projection to the SI than does the medial segment.')

The distribution of axons anterogradely labelled from an injection of WGA-HRP into the dorsomedial medulla, together with previously reported observations (Ricardo and Koh, '78, see their Fig. 2E-G), suggests a similarly preferential innervation of the dorsal SI by at least the caudal part of the nucleus of the solitary tract.

Projections directed preferentially toward all the forebrain associates of the dorsal SI-except the basolateral nucleus-rather than those of the ventral SI (Fig. 16), arise from lateral subnuclei of the parabrachial nucleus and less densely from the latter's medial segment (present study; Norgren, '76; Saper and Loewy, '80; Fulwiler and Saper, '84).

Observations following PHA-L deposits in the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis, amygdala, and hypothalamus, or WGA-HRP injections in the pons, confirmed earlier reports that the parabrachial nucleus receives similarly weighted return projections from the same structures (Krettek and Price, '78a; Saper et al., '79a; Holstege et al., '85).

In the rat, the nucleus of the solitary tract caudal to the obex projects heavily to the lateral parabrachial nucleus well as to the forebrain associates of the dorsal SI (again apparently excluding the basolateral nucleus of the amygdala) (Ricardo and Koh, '78).

These forebrain structures, in turn, project back to the complex formed by the NTS and dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus (present study; Saper et al., '76b; Price and Amaral, '81; Schwaber et al., '82).

Saper and his colleagues ('76b) report projections terminating still further caudally, in the intermediolateral column of the thoracic spinal cord, arising from the paraventricular nucleus, dorsomedial and posterior hypothalamus, and the "perifornical" LH, adding that the distribution of labelled cells in the hypothalamus is identical following HRP injections into the parabrachial nucleus, medulla, or thoracic spinal cord.

The nucleus of the solitary tract receives general visceral afferents from the periphery that terminate most heavily caudal to the obex, and gustatory afferents that primarily innervate its rostral portion.

The dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus contains preganglionic motor neurons of the parasympathetic nervous system, and preganglionic sympathetic neurons are found in the intermediolateral column of the thoracic spinal cord.
Thus, the set of highly interconnected cell groups associated with the dorsal SI includes structures that relay primary visceral sensory afferents or directly control autonomic function.
Some forebrain associates of the dorsal SI, illustrated in Figure 16, maintain a more limited set of connections with other members of the group.

For example, the basolateral nucleus of the amygdala and the lateral segment of the central nucleus project into the continuum formed by the medial part of the central nucleus, dorsal SI, and lateral BNS (present study, de Olmos, '72; Krettek and Price, '78a).
Cells within the continuum return the projection to the basolateral nucleus but not to the lateral part of the central nucleus (present study, Grove, '88).

As noted above, the basolateral nucleus is not prominently connected with the hypothalamic or caudal brainstem associates of the dorsal SI, but the lateral segment of the central nucleus receives notable projections from the parabrachial nucleus and NTS (present study; Norgren, '76; Ricardo and Koh, '78; Saper and Loewy, '80).

Finally, the fundus of the striatum innervates both the dorsalmost SI and the lateral part of the central nucleus (present study) and receives slight to moderate projections from at least the lateral BNS, lateral hypothalamus, SI, and basolateral and basomedial nuclei of the amygdala (present study; Kelley et al., '82; Zaborszky et al., '85; Grove, '88).
Figure 16 illustrates only those structures whose selective associations with one or the other SI division have been demonstrated in the present study.
Other cell groups in the thalamus or caudal brainstem that appear to innervate the SI may, of course, also be preferentially connected with a single division.

For example, amygdalopetal efferents of the thalamic paraventricular and central medial nuclei selectively innervate the central and basolateral nuclei (Turner and Herkenham, '81) and are thus likely to traverse, and perhaps terminate in, the dorsal division of the SI.
Possible selectivity of cortical projections to the
SZ.

Injections of WGA-HRP centered in the ventral SI labelled cells primarily in piriform and entorhinal cortex with only a cell or two in the most ventral insular cortex, whereas tracer deposits involving both SI divisions labelled additional perikarya in infralimbic, prelimbic, anterior cingulate, insular, and perirhinal cortices.

IR cases to be described in a separate report, PHA-L deposits in medial prefrontal, insular, and entorhinal cortices filled smooth and varicose axons in the SI, but none produced fiber labelling that was notably selective for either SI division.
However, the organization of corticofugal fibers may simply not have been revealed by the limited series of available PHAL cases.

Suggestive of this, Saper ('82a) indicates that caudal insular cortex projects preferentially to the lateral BNS, dorsal amygdala, and a region in between that may correspond to the dorsal SI (see Saper, '82a, Fig. 2).
In the rat, several subcortical cell groups associated with the dorsal SI maintain connections with cortices that innervate the SI.

Infralimbic, prelimbic, anterior cingulate, insular, piriform, and entorhinal cortex project to and receive projections from the basolateral nucleus of the amygdala, and all but anterior cingulate cortex have also been reported to innervate the central nucleus (for review, see de Olmos et al., '85).
Additionally, the caudolateral zone of the lateral hypothalamus innervates medial prefrontal and insular cortex (Saper, '85).

The medial parabrachial nucleus is reciprocally connected with the most ventral infralimbic cortex and a large rostrocaudal extent of insular cortex (Saper and Loewy, '80; Saper, '82b; Fulwiler and Saper, '84) that includes areas identified as containing gustatory and visceral sensory representations.
Neural associates of the ventral SZ.
As illustrated in Figure 16, structures preferentially interconnected with the ventral SI form a complementary set to the forebrain associates of the dorsal division.

Present findings indicate only a modest innervation of the dorsal SI from the anterior amygdaloid area and the region ventral to the central nucleus that may include part of the basomedial nucleus as delineated by Krettek and Price ('78b).

These ventral regions of the amygdala instead project heavily to the ventral SI, which also receives selective innervation from the rostral two-thirds of the medial nucleus, medial BNS, medial preoptic area, anterior hypothalamus, the most medial part of the lateral hypothalamus, and the ventromedial hypothalamus.
The medial BNS, ventral SI, and ventromedial amygdala maintain reciprocal connections with one another (present study, Krettek and Price, '78a; de Olmos et al., '85; Grove, '88).

Further, the medial BNS, ventral SI, and rostral parts of both the medial nucleus and the amygdaloid area beneath the central nucleus all project to the anterior hypothalamus, medial portions of the preoptic area and lateral hypothalamus, and the dorsomedial and ventromedial hypothalamus (present study; Krettek and Price, '78a; Berk and Finkelstein, '81; Price, '81; Grove, '88).
Present findings from PHA-L and WGA-HRP experiments indicate the same hypothalamic regions return projections to the ventromedial amygdala and ventral SI.
At least the caudomedial hypothalamus innervates the medial BNS as well (present study; Saper et al., '76a).
Finally, these hypothalamic areas may maintain connections among themselves (present study; Conrad and Pfaff, '76a,b; Saper et al., '76a, '79a,b; Swanson, '76; Berk and Finkelstein, '81).

In the rodent, the rostral part of the medial nucleus, anterior amygdaloid area, and medial BNS lie along conduction lines leading from the main olfactory bulb (OB) or accessory olfactory bulb (AOB), which relay chemosensory information from, respectively, the olfactory epithelium and vomeronasal organ (a second chemosensory organ found in the nasal cavity of many nonprimate mammals.)
The two pathways may overlap in the rostral medial nucleus (for review, see de Olmos et al., '85; Switzer et al., '85).
Projections back to the AOB arise from the medial nucleus of the amygdala, medial BNS, and the ventral SI (de Olmos et al., '85; Grove, '88).
The OB is innervated, in turn, by at least the SI (Grove, '88) and anterior amygdaloid area (for review of the return projections to OB and AOB, see de Olmos et al., '85; Switzer et al., '85).
Possible nonselective afferents to the SZ.
Several structures that project preferentially to one SI division innervate the other subregion at least sparsely (Figs. 4, 8-11).

In particular, WGA-HRP deposits involving either SI division labelled several cells in the dorsomedial hypothalamus, an area of the lateral hypothalamus just ventral to the fornix, the posterior hypothalamus, the supramammillary region, the ventral tegmental area, and the peripeduncular area.
PHA-L deposits centered in the last three regions confirmed projections to the SI that appeared nonselective.
(Small subregions within these areas may, of course, maintain preferential, separate projections to each SI division, but the present study provided no evidence of such a parcellation.)

Findings from both WGA-HRP and PHA-L experiments further suggested that the dorsomedial and posterior hypothalamus, supramammillary region, and peripeduncular area project to at least some of the amygdaloid and hypothalamic associates of both SI divisions.

At least in the case of the peripeduncular area, however, projections do not appear to reach all forebrain associates of the dorsal SI, avoiding the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus and the basolateral nucleus of the amygdala and distributing only modestly in the central nucleus.
Of the globus that selectively
innervate the cholinergic cell-rich region
The present study additionally revealed several afferents to the cholinergic cell-rich region of the GP that bring their target cells into the general circuitries described above.
In the following, three categories of afferents are described in relation to the routes of access they take.

PHA-L experiments revealed that a few axons of both the stria terminalis and AP become detached from these main fiber bundles and form slender bridges between the two pathways by running along the lateral face of the internal capsule, or lateral margin of the GP.

At least a few sparsely varicose axons arising from the central nucleus of the amygdala, dorsal SI (Grove, '881, lateral bed nucleus of the stria terminalis, lateral hypothalamus, and parabrachial nucleus follow this route.

Fibers from the ventral tegmental area and dorsal raphe also spread along the lateral face of the internal capsule, although varicose axons from at least the dorsal raphe appear in the main mass of the globus pallidus as well.
Finally, although their source was not determined, some of these "bridging" axons have been the identified as immunoreactive for tyrosine hydroxylase (Fig.
21, or angiotensin I1 (Lind et al., '85).

In the monkey, too, a few axons from the central nucleus of the amygdala course along the fiber laminae that surround the GP, and are distributed among the large cells that extend into these regions from the basal nucleus of Meynert (Price and Amaral, '81).
In both rat and monkey, this category of afferents to areas in and around the GP strays from fiber contingents that more densely innervate the SI (specifically the dorsal SI in the rat).
Such sparse fibers appear likely to provide a significant innervation only to cells that receive relatively few inputs from any other source.
It is therefore interesting that intrapallidal cholinergic cells are of this sparsely afferented type (Ingham et al., '85).
A greater volume of more richly varicose fibers courses over a second route into the ventromedial and caudal GP.
Efferents from the peripeduncular area penetrate the cerebral peduncle and pass rostrally over the supraoptic decussation to be distributed selectively in the cholinergic cellrich region of the GP.

Just as the peripeduncular nucleus in the monkey projects more heavily to the caudal cell islands of the basal nucleus of Meynert (Jones et al., '76), the PPA in the rat innervates the comparatively caudal cholinergic cell-rich GP more densely than it does the SI.

However, afferents to the SI and amygdala arise not only from the PPA proper but from a continuum extending rolitrally from the PPA to incorporate the parvocellular part of the subparafascicular nucleus (present study; Mehler, '80; Mehler et al., '81; LeDoux et al., '85).

The continuum is identified 1) by the finding that cells throughout its extent are labelled by retrograde tracers placed in the SI or amygdala (present study; Mehler, '80; Mehler et al., '81; LeDoux et al., '85) and 2) by the somatostatin (Graybiel and Elde, '83) and enkephalin-immunoreactive fibers (unpublished observation) that permeate it.
It may be that rostral parts of the continuum (not injected with PHA-L in the present study) may project more densely to more rostral parts of the cholinergic basal forebrain. including the SI.
Saper ('84) has proposed that a third route, the internal capsule, may supply the region with a variety of cortical inputs.

Further, Haring and Wang ('86) have reported evidence from retrograde axonal transport experiments that cortical innervatibn is not typical of the GP as a whole but is directed selectively toward its medial part.

Findings from a few PHA-L cases available to the present studv revealed that axons from at least the rostral-medial prefiontal and insular cortex do display terminal varicosities in the internal capsule and medial GP, as well as in the SI.
However, not all cortical areas may give rise to efferents that innervate the GP and the intracapsular gray as they traverse the region.
PHA-L deposits in cingulate cortex caudal to the genu of the corpus callosum, for example, filled only smooth, nonterminating fibers in the GP and IC.

Additionally, and surprisingly, the medial GP is not the only target of corticopallidal afferents: a few axons labelled from PHAL injections into motor cortex displayed terminal swelling:; in the lateral, but not medial, part of the GP (Grove, in preparation).
In summary, a variety of afferents to the SI, in particulaito its dorsal division, are shared at least sparsely by neurons within the cholinergic cell-rich region of the GP.
Since projections from this area to the cortex are well documented, it appears that the cholinergic cell-rich region of GP shares a kinship with the SI in both afferent and efferent connections.
Pallidal features of the dorsalmost part of the SI The separation of cell populations typical of the GP or SI may also be incomplete in the dorsalmost part of the SI.

This region is marked by enkephalin-immunoreactive "woolly fibers," a terminal configuration that is characteristic of the projection from the striatum to the GP and ventral pallidum (Haber and Elde, '81; Switzer et al., '82; Zaborszky et al., '82; Haber and Nauta, '83).
Further, the dorsalmost SI does receive a projection from the striatum (Fig. 151, and appears to project back to the striatum as well (Grove, '88).
Such observations suggest the dorsalmost S[ should be viewed as, or as mixed with, pallidal tissue.
However, in receiving innervation from the striatum and from ENK-IR woolly fibers, the SI resembles not only the GP and VP but also certain parts of the amygdala.
Both features are shared by the lateral segment of the central nucleus and the most lateral part of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis (present study, Nauta et al., '78; Haber and Nauta, '83).
Moreover, the striatum has not been directly established as an origin of enkephalinergic innervation in any of these areas, and other sources are possible.

For example, PHA-L-filled axon terminals, labelled from deposits in the central nucleus of the amygdala, bed nucleus of the stria terminalis, or parabrachial nucleus were occasionally seen to outline a single cell body or dendrite in the SI in "woolly fiber" fashion (see Results).
Each of these nuclei contains enkephalinergic neurons (Mantyh and Hunt, '84; Veening et al., '84).
Indeed, the central nucleus has been shown by lesion experiments to provide enkephalinergic afferents to the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis, some of which traverse the SI (Rao et al., '87).
Only a similar study can finally determine the origin of ENK-IR woolly fibers, in particular, in the SI.
The dorsalmost strip of the SI also differs from the adjacent GP and VP in several respects, resembling instead the rest of the SI.
First, present findings do not indicate a heavy innervation by the subthalamic nucleus, the second major source of input to the GP-VP continuum.
Second, the dorsalmost SI is the target not of just a few AP fibers, like the cholinergic cell-rich region of the GP, but of many.

These fibers include afferents from regions that themselves display "pallidal" features-the lateral segment of the central nucleus of the amygdala, lateral part of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis, and the perifornical zone of the lateral hypothalamus-but also from the basolateral nucleus of the amygdala, caudolateral zone of the lateral hypothalamus, parabrachial nucleus, and possibly nucleus of the solitary tract.

Third, the dorsalmost SI, like the rest of the dorsal division, can be distinguished from most of the GP and VP in material stained to reveal tyrosine hydroxylase-immunoreactive axon terminals (Fig. 2), or a cupric-silver reaction product (de Olmos, '72; de Olmos et al., '85).
Finally, the entire SI displays modest, even staining in Timm preparations, whereas the VP and GP appear patchy (Ottersen, '80; de Olmos et al., '85).

At present, perhaps the only possible conclusion regarding the dorsalmost strip of the SI is that the region appears to combine certain histochemical and connectional features of both the overlying GP and the rest of the SI, forming a more complex tissue than either one.
Innervation of the cholinergc neurons within the globus pallidus and substantia innominata
The most striking constituent of the SI in the primate is the basal nucleus of Meynert (BNM), which provides most of the cholinergic innervation of the neocortex and amygdala (Mesulam et al., '83a).

In the rat, too, although there is no infrapallidal cell mass comparable to the BNM, the SI contains a characteristic scattering of cholinergic neurons that also project to neocortical and amygdaloid targets (Lehmann et al., '80; Big1 et al., '82; Woolf and Butcher, '82; Grove et al., '83; McKinney et al., '83; Mesulam et al., '83a,b; Rye et al., '84b; Saper, '84; Carlsen et al., '85; Fisher et al., '86).
This dispersed cell population is helpful in determining the rough boundaries that can be drawn around the SI (see Results).

Cholinergic neurons in the SI, however, are only part of a loosely continuous mass of cholinergic cells in the basal forebrain that extends from the medial septum and the nucleus of the diagonal band to the caudal GP, and it has been proposed that this cell population may form a single anatomical and functional entity (Schwaber et al., '87).

It is thus plausible that cholinergic cells that invade the SI maintain their own characteristic afferent and efferent connections, related to those of other basal forebrain cholinergic neurons, but wholly unrelated to those of neighboring, noncholinergic SI cells.

Alternatively, cholinergic cells may take a strategic advantage from their wide scattering in different parts of the basal forebrain, participating in the distinctive circuitry of these different regions.
Resolving this issue requires considerable further investigation.

However, some observations from the present study bear on one important question-namely, what are the afferent connections of the cholinergic neurons, and how do they compare to those of neighboring noncholinergic cells?
The cell bodies and proximal dendrites of cholinergic cells in the GP and SI are typically contacted only sparsely by synaptic axonal boutons (Ingham et al., '85).
Probably for this reason, in tissue sections processed to show both forms of immunoreactivity, juxtapositions between PHA-L-labelled axonal varicosities and ChAT-IR neurons were seen only rarely.

Synaptic relations can be identified conclusively only in the electron microscope, since a physical contact between a labelled axon terminal and an identified cell seen in the light microscope may well be coincidental: the bouton in reality makes synaptic contact with an adjacent, unlabelled element, or forms no synapse at all.
For this reason, only contacts by several PHA-L-labelled varicosities on the same CUT-IR cell were taken as providing strong light microscopic evidence of innervation.

Such terminal configurations were particularly difficult to find but were noted in the SI or GP following PHA-L injections into the ventral tegmental area, dorsal raphe, peripeduncular nucleus, and caudomedial hypothalamus.
Pending confirmation in an ultrastructural study, such findings suggest that several sources of innervation to the SI may provide afferents to the cholinergic cells in the region.

Electron microscopic observations following knife cuts at the mesodiencephalic border provide supportive evidence of synaptic inputs to cholinergic SI cells from caudal brainstem structures (Zaborszky et aI., '86b).
In the present study, fibers originating from the amygdala and some cortical areas were observed to form terminal varicosities, sometimes in profusion, in regions containing cholinergic cells.
Nonetheless, only occasional single contacts were observed between PHA-L-labelled axanal swellings and CMT-IR elements.

Inputs selective for distal Darts of the cholinermc cells' dendrites would be missed; however, since the reuaction product marking ChAT rarely filled that part of the cell densely enough to be identifiable in the light microscope.

Indeed, electron microscopic studies employing WGA-HRP as an anterograde axonal tracer have suggested synaptic input from the cortex to cortically projecting basal forebrain neurons (Lehmann and Saper, '85) and from the basolateral nucleus of the amygdala to amygdala-projecting or ChAT-immunoreactive cells (Zaborszky et al., '84).
Studies in the monkey provide additional evidence for a variety of afferents to cholinergic cells in the SI.
In primates, most cholinergic neurons in the SI cluster to form the cell islands of the basal nucleus of Meynert.
Even when seen in exclusively light microscopic examination, anterograde axonal labelling over these clusters thus strongly suggests innervation of the cholinergic cells.

Such labelling has been reported in autoradiographic studies of the efferents of the peripeduncular nucleus and ventromedial hypothalamus (Jones et al., '761, central nucleus of the amygdala (Price and Amaral, '81), other sites in the amygdala (Russchen et al., '851, and orbital, insular, and anterior et temporal cortex (Mesulam and Mufson, '84; Russchen al., '85).

Several lines of evidence suggest a general conclusion: cholinergic neurons do not form an entirely separate, intruding cell group in the SI and GP but participate to some extent in the afferent circuitry of local neurons.

In the monkey, axons arising from the peripeduncular nucleus, ventromedial hypothalamus, amygdala, and cortex not only appear to terminate over the BNM cell clusters but also distribute over other parts of the SI where comparatively few cholinergic cells are dispersed (Jones et al., '76; Price and Amaral, '81; Russchen et al., '85).

In the rat, the moderate-to-high density of axon terminal labelling in the SI and cholinergic cell-rich GP that follows PHA-L injections into the peripeduncular area or amygdala of the rat, and sometimes locally appears as "empty basket" formations of labelled terminals, suggests that a sparsely innervated cell type such as the cholinergic neuron cannot be the only target.

Finally, both lightand electron-microscopic evidence indicates that at least some intrapallidal cholinergic cells receive innervation from the striatum (Grove et al., '86; Grove and Ingham, '861, a source of input they share with noncholinergic, typically pallidal cells.
FUNCTIONAL CONSIDERATIONS
Three observations, based on the present anatomical findings, could be useful in guiding physiological and behavioral studies of the SI.

First, the SI is likely to be functionally heterogeneous: the dorsal and ventral divisions receive afferent input from largely different sets of struttures and maintain similarly distinct efferent connections (Grove, '88).

Second, the cholinergic cell GOUP, whose functional role is of great current interest, is distributed in both divisions and appears likely to Participate in the afferent circuitry of neighboring, noncholinergic cells.
Third7 and perhaps most important, in designing functional studies of the SI, investigators might take a cue from its strong neuroanatomical affiliation with the amygdala.
More detailed anatomical studies are needed, but it seems likely that these generalizations are also applicable to the primate.
The organisation of the SI into two divisions, demonstrated here in the rat, reflects the relative position of axons that compose the AP in its traverse of the SI.
To the extent that different contingents of fibers in the AP have a comparable organisation in other species, SI divisions defined by differential afferentation should be identifiable.

Further, heavy projections between the amYgdala and the SI in the monkey have been demonstrated (Russchen et al., '85; Aggleton et al., '87), and as noted above, a comparison of retrograde tracer studies suggests that the afferent connections of the SI and amygdala in the monkey are highly similar (Aggleton et al., '80; Mehler, '80; Norita and Kawamura, '80; Mehler et al., '81; Russchen et al., '85).
Possible functional associations of the dorsal SI

Several of the interconnected forebrain and brainstem structures associated with the dorsal SI appear to form a functional assembly concerned at least in part with monitoring and influencing autonomic and visceral functions.

Changes in blood pressure and heart rate are induced by ablation or stimulation in the posterior insular cortex, ventral infralimbic cortex, bed nucleus of the stria terminalis, central nucleus of the amygdala, dorsomedial nucleus of the hypothalamus, dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus, and nucleus of the solitary tract.

Respiratory function is modified by stimulation or ablation of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis, central nucleus, or medial parabrachial nucleus, and changes in GI motility or secretory activity are elicited by stimulation of the central nucleus (for review, see Kaada, '72; Ricardo and Koh, '78; Price and Amaral, '81; Ruggiero et al., '87).
Stimulation in or ablation of the amygdaloid affiliates of the dorsal SI can additionally evoke or disrupt coordinated behaviors that prominently include autonomic components.

The central and basolateral nuclei of the amygdala are effective stimulation sites for eliciting the defense reaction, an integrated set of autonomic, endocrine, and somatic motor responses (for review, see Kaada, '721, and ablation of the central nucleus has been reported to suppress autonomic and behavioral components of a conditioned fear response (Iwata et al., '86).
Possible functional associations of the ventral S%

Indicating that the circuitries associated with the two SI divisions are functionally as well as anatomically distinct, cell groups connected with the ventral SI have been implicated in quite different species-specific behaviors.

Stimulation in the corticomedial nuclei of the amygdala in the monkey is comparatively ineffective in eliciting defense and flight responses, and instead modifies feeding and sexual behaviors (for review, see Kaada, '72).

In the rodent, lesions in the medial nucleus of the amygdala, medial preoptic area, or caudomedial hypothalamus suppress mi2ting and investigatory behaviors (Heimer and Larsson, '67; paxinos and ~ i ~ '73; & ~ Lehman , et al., '80) apparent,ly due, at least in the of amygdaloid lesions, to disrupted processing of chemosensory input from the olfactory and vomeronasa~ organs (Lehman et al., '80).

It might be noted that lesions in the peripeduncular area, which innervates both ventral and dorsal divisions ofthe SI and at least of their forebrain associates, have been reported to disrupt aspects of sexual behavior in the female rat (see Arnault and Roger, '87, for review), as well as autonomic responses and emotional behavior conditioned to acoustic stimuli (LeDoux et al., '84; Jarrell et al., '86).

Although experiments have indicated functional heterogeneity in the amygdala, an view of the role of this structure has proved useful in guiding behavioral studies and may be applicable to the SI as well.
This view, that the amygdala is a route through which complex sensory stimuli elicit appropriate affective re.

sponses ( ~ l i '72; ~ ~ ~ , l '78; Mishkin ~ ~ and ~ Aggleton, , '81)' appears to be supported by the anatomical position of the amygdala (shared by the SI), receiving afferents that can be presumed to relay sensory information from insular alld temporal polysensory association cortices and maintainirlg widespread descending projections to the hypothalamus arld caudal brainstem. price and Amaral('81) hypothesize that the central nucleus may, thus, mediate between the perception of a fear-evoking situation and the mobilization of an appropriate autonomic and behavioral response.
It can be conjectured that the medial nucleus might play an analogous role in the initiation of sexual and investigatory behavior in response to complex chemosensory stimuli.
Memory function

Consistent with the general view of amygdala function expressed above, lesions in that structure in the monkey disrupt a specific type of learning, the association of stimulus and reward (Jones and Mishkin, '72; Mishkin and Aggleton, '81).
Further observations, however, indicate a wider involvement by the amygdala in memory.

Ablation of the amygdala impairs a monkey's ability to form cross-modal associations, that is, to recognize by vision an object it has previously examined by touch (Murray and Mishkin, '851, and combined lesions of the amygdala and hippocampus produce an analog of human global amnesia (Mishkin, '78).
Against this background, the suggestion that the affXated SI may also be involved in memory is particularly noteworthy.

Such a proposal has previously focused on the cholinergic cell population in the SI, deriving from observations that cholinergic drugs affect performance in tests of memory (for review, see Aigner and Mishkin, '861, and that, in Alzheimer's disease (AD), degenerative changes that occur in the pathway from the cholinergic basal nucleus of Meynert to cortex appear correlated with the degree of memory loss (for review, see Corkin, '81; Bartus et al., '82; Rossor et al., '82).
However, in both cases, memory could be influenced by altered function in brain structures other than the SI (Davies, '83; Hyman et al., '84).
Several studies have further investigated the role of the cholinergic SI cell population in memory with experimental lesions confined to the basal forebrain.

Lesions that deplete cortical cholinergic markers in the rat have been observed to impair performance in several tasks that involve a memory component, although in many such studies the possibility that this is caused by the disruption of some nonmnemonic process has not been discounted (for review, see Salamone, '86).

In the monkey, Aigner and colleagues ('84) have shown that combined ablation of the septum, diagonal band, and basal nucleus disrupts recognition memory; they propose that the impairment results from compromised function in both the hippocampus and amygdala, targets of cholinergic projections from, respectively, the medial septum and basal nucleus.

However, although the excitotoxic lesions made by Aigner and colleagues would spare fibers passing through the lesion sites, they would also destroy noncholinergic cells in the SI and disrupt conduction pathways that incorporate such neurons.
New information from the present study and from a cornpanion investigation provides a firm neuroanatomical basis a role for the SI in memory and suggests a for novel view.
Such a functional contribution, in the new view, may go beyond the cholinergic modulation of activity in other memory-related structures.

The complete set of afferent and efferent connections maintained by the SI appears highly similar, if not identical, to that of the amygdala, and in the case of the latter structure, these associations support a well-documented role in memory.
Thus, neuroanatomical evidence suggests the SI may contribute to normal memory function in strong affiliation with the amygdala.
Shifting attention to the neuroanatomical character of the SI as a whole, rather than focusing only on its cholinergic projections elsewhere, also suggests a new emphasis for functional studies.
A specific illustration can be offered in conclusion.

A recent study (Richardson and DeLong, '86) of the response properties of neurons in the basal nucleus of Meynert was motivated by a focus on its cholinergic projection to cortex, specifically its innervation of dorsolateral prefrontal cortex in the monkey.
Ablation or cooling of this part of the cortex disrupts performance in a delayed response task (Fuster and Alexander, '70; Goldman and Rosvold, '70), as do cholinergic antagonists (Bartus, '78).

Neurons in dorsolateral prefrontal cortex display altered firing rates during the delay period of the task (Fuster, '73; Kojima and Goldman-Rakic, '82), and if BNM neurons influence response properties in such cells they might exhibit similar firing rate changes themselves.

However, Richardson and DeLong ('86) found that few neurons in the basal nucleus of Meynert change their rate of discharge during the delay period of a task in which a monkey is required to discriminate between two spatial locations for reward.

Instead, these authors observed that most recorded cells altered their firing rate as the monkey selected, reached for, or received its reward (Richardson and DeLong, '86), consistent with similar previous observations (DeLong, '71; Burton et al., '75; Rolls et al., '79, '80; Rigdon and Pirch, '86).
These results provide little evidence for a direct involvement of BNM in the memory component of the task but support a relation to aspects of reward acquisition.

An emphasis on the connectional similarity between the SI and the amygdala, however, suggests the type of task described by Richardson and DeLong may not be best suited to revealing the particular contribution of the SI to memory.

Ablation studies have not implicated the amygdala in memory for spatial location (Jones and Mishkin, '72; Mishkin and Aggleton, '811, and lesions must be placed in both the amygdala and hippocampus to disrupt performance in several object discrimination tasks involving a delay (Mishkin, '78; Mishkin and Aggleton, '81).
However, ablation of the amygdala alone dramatically impairs an animal's ability to form associations between particular objects and reward conditions.

Thus, the strong affiliation between the SI and the amygdala, especially in light of the apparent involvement of SI neurons with reward acquisition, suggests that a focus on memory for object-reward associations might prove fruitful in both ablation and single-unit recording studies of the SI.
